techniques.name: Anulom Vilom (Alternate Nostril Breathing)
techniques.description: ALU Loma Viloma Prakriya, also known as Anulom Vilom or Alternate Nostril Breathing, is a yogic breathing technique that involves inhaling and exhaling through alternating nostrils. This practice is believed to promote physical and mental well-being by balancing energy channels, improving respiratory function, and reducing stress.
benefits: Calms the mind and nervous system
Balances energy channels (Ida and Pingala nadis)
techniques.setup: Find a comfortable seated position in Sukhasana (easy pose), Padmasana (lotus pose), or any other posture that allows you to sit with a straight spine.
steps: Prepare your hand: Use your right hand to form the Nasagra mudra (thumb and index finger position)
Close your right nostril with your thumb and inhale deeply through your left nostril
Hold and switch: Close both nostrils, hold your breath briefly, then release your right nostril and exhale slowly through it
Reverse the process: Inhale through the right nostril, hold your breath with both nostrils closed, then exhale through the left nostril
Continue the cycle: This completes one round. Continue alternating between nostrils for the desired number of rounds
contraindications: Avoid if you have severe respiratory conditions
Practice gently - never force the breath
Stop if you feel dizzy or uncomfortable
Consult a teacher if you're new to pranayama

dosha_information.effects: Balances nervous system, harmonizes energy channels, reduces mental agitation
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Excellent for Vata imbalances, anxiety, and nervous system disorders

guna_information.effects: Promotes mental clarity, inner peace, and spiritual awareness

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Slow, deep inhalation through alternate nostrils
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Brief retention with both nostrils closed
breathing_pattern.out_rechaka: Slow, controlled exhalation through alternate nostril

techniques.ratio_info: Often practiced with 1:1:1:1 ratio (inhale:retain:exhale:pause) or can be done without retention
techniques.sanskrit_meaning: Anulom = with the grain/natural order; Vilom = against the grain; Prakriya = process/method
techniques.traditional_source: Classical pranayama from Hatha Yoga tradition
seasonal_use: especially beneficial in autumn and winter
additional_notes: One of the most fundamental and accessible pranayama practices
Can be practiced by beginners and advanced practitioners
Forms the foundation for many other breathing techniques

techniques.name: Bandha Sequences (Morning Practice)
techniques.description: Comprehensive bandha practice sequence combining asanas with the three primary bandhas (Mula, Uddiyana, and Jalandhara). This sequence is designed as a morning practice to awaken and direct prana through energy locks.
benefits: Strengthens core muscles and pelvic floor
Improves energy circulation and prana control
techniques.setup: Begin in Vajrasana (thunderbolt pose) or other comfortable seated position. Ensure the spine is erect and the body is relaxed but alert.
steps: - Dharmikasana with Sparsh (lower awareness touch) - 3 repetitions
- Suptha Vajrasana with Kriya and Hasta mudras - 3 repetitions
- Vajrasana with Hasta mudras and sound - 3 repetitions
- Apply Agni Sara (abdominal pumping) as preparation
- Inhale: Apply Mula and Jalandhara bandhas simultaneously
- Hold breath with bandhas engaged (8-16 counts)
- Exhale: Release into Bandha Trayam (all three bandhas)
- Eka Pada Uttanasana with Mayurasana and Ashwini mudra
- Return to Vajrasana with full awareness
contraindications: Avoid with hernia or abdominal surgery history
Stop if experiencing dizziness or strain
Not recommended with high blood pressure (avoid breath retention)

dosha_information.effects: Grounds scattered Vata energy, strengthens core stability, balances nervous system
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Excellent for Vata imbalances, anxiety, and core weakness

guna_information.effects: Builds inner strength and dynamic energy control, prepares for Sattvic practices

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Deep inhalation while engaging Mula and Jalandhara bandhas
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Breath retention with bandhas held (8-16 counts)
breathing_pattern.out_rechaka: Controlled exhalation applying Bandha Trayam (all three bandhas)
breathing_pattern.shunyaka: Brief retention on empty breath with bandhas (5-8 counts)

techniques.sanskrit_meaning: Bandha = lock/bond; Trayam = three; Energy locks for prana direction
techniques.traditional_source: Classical Hatha Yoga tradition, referenced in Hatha Yoga Pradipika
seasonal_use: particularly beneficial in spring and summer
additional_notes: This is an advanced practice requiring proper foundation
Begin with individual bandhas before attempting sequences
Morning practice is ideal when energy is fresh
Builds systematic control over subtle energy (prana)
Forms foundation for advanced Hatha Yoga practices
Philosophical note: 'Awareness of awareness is important'
Traditional wisdom: 'Living together makes rough stones smooth'
Practice attitude: 'Smile (Mudita mudra), stickability, will power, flexibility'

techniques.name: Adham Pranayama (Lower Lung Expansion)
techniques.description: Hathenas technique focusing on lower lung expansion through specific asana sequences and breathing practices. Targets the lower lobes of the lungs for complete respiratory function.
steps: Sapurna Ustrasana 1: Arms hanging down naturally
Pari Purna Ustrasana 2: Hands touch heels, only toes on floor, lift hips
Purna Ustrasana 3: Hands touch heels, entire foot on floor
Shasha variation: Foreheads on floor in front of knees
Maintain awareness on lower lung expansion throughout
techniques.focus_technique: Sparsha (touch awareness) - front 3x, side 3x, back 3x on lower lung region
benefits: Supports digestive function through diaphragm massage
techniques.sequence: Sparsha  Hathena Kriyas  Sasha  Hasta Mudras  Nishpandha  Makarasana  Bhujangasana  Shashankasana (performed separately for lower region)
techniques.post_practice: Mukha Bhastrika 3 times  Dharmikasana  Suptha Vajrasana  Vajrasana  Turn mat north-south  Kaya Kriya 3x each  All together 3x  With Pranav  Savasana with polarity Savitri breath 20 minutes
contraindications: Not recommended during pregnancy (modified approach needed)

dosha_information.effects: Energizes lower lung region, improves sluggish breathing patterns
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Excellent for Kapha imbalances and respiratory stagnation

guna_information.effects: Activates energy in lower body, stimulates digestive fire

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Deep inhalation focusing on lower lung expansion
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Brief retention to maximize lower lung filling
breathing_pattern.out_rechaka: Slow exhalation maintaining lower lung awareness

additional_notes: Part of complete Hathenas lung expansion system
Practice in sequence: Lower  Mid  Upper  Complete
Combines asana with pranayama for optimal results

techniques.name: Madhyam Pranayama (Mid Lung Expansion)
techniques.description: Hathenas technique targeting the middle lung region through Matsyasana variations and specific breathing awareness.
steps: Place elbows on floor for support
Sapurna Matsyanasa: Head hanging down naturally
Purna Matsyasana: Top of head on floor, hands on thighs
Pari Purna Matsyasana: Full fish pose with hands touching feet
Shasha 2: Palms on floor front of knees, arch spine back
Focus middle chest forward, emphasize middle lung expansion
techniques.focus_technique: Sparsha (touch awareness) - front 3x, side 3x, back 3x on middle lung region
benefits: Enhances emotional balance through heart opening
techniques.sequence: Sparsha  Hathena Kriyas  Sasha  Hasta Mudras  Nishpandha  Makarasana  Bhujangasana  Shashankasana (performed separately for middle region)
techniques.post_practice: Mukha Bhastrika 3 times  Dharmikasana  Suptha Vajrasana  Vajrasana  Turn mat north-south  Kaya Kriya 3x each  All together 3x  With Pranav  Savasana with polarity Savitri breath 20 minutes

dosha_information.effects: Balances heart fire, regulates circulation and metabolism
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Good for Pitta imbalances affecting heart and circulation

guna_information.effects: Opens heart center, promotes emotional balance and clarity

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Focused inhalation expanding middle chest region

additional_notes: Second phase of Hathenas lung expansion sequence
Emphasizes heart opening and emotional release

techniques.name: Adhyama Pranayama (Upper Lung Expansion)
techniques.description: Hathenas technique for upper lung expansion through Mahamudra variations, targeting the apex of the lungs and collar bone region.
steps: Mahamudra 1: Breathing out, head on floor (Nari Bindu point)
Arms up with gentle pumps on empty lungs
Mahamudra 2: Exhaling, bring head to floor close to knees
Hands clasped, palms up, perform pumping action
Nikunja: Chatuspada with elbows splayed on floor
Upper chest on floor, head to right 3x, then left 3x
Sasha: Dharmik position, roll forward on head, back to Dharmik, return to Vaj
techniques.focus_technique: Collar bone awareness 3x, top of thighs 3x, back shoulder blades 3x
techniques.sequence: Sparsha  Hathena Kriyas  Sasha  Hasta Mudras  Nishpandha  Makarasana  Bhujangasana  Shashankasana (performed separately for upper region)
techniques.post_practice: Mukha Bhastrika 3 times  Dharmikasana  Suptha Vajrasana  Vajrasana  Turn mat north-south  Kaya Kriya 3x each  All together 3x  With Pranav  Savasana with polarity Savitri breath 20 minutes
contraindications: Not recommended with recent head/neck injuries

dosha_information.effects: Calms nervous system, improves upper respiratory function
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Excellent for Vata imbalances affecting head and neck

guna_information.effects: Promotes mental clarity, enhances spiritual awareness

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Gentle inhalation focusing on upper chest and collar bone expansion
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Light retention emphasizing upper lung filling
breathing_pattern.out_rechaka: Smooth exhalation maintaining upper chest awareness

additional_notes: Third phase of Hathenas lung expansion sequence

techniques.name: Mahat Pranayama (Complete Lung Expansion)
techniques.description: The culminating Hathenas technique integrating all three lung regions (lower, middle, upper) for complete respiratory mastery and nervous system balance.
steps: Vyagraha (Chatuspadasana): Head and neck up, spine down
Exhale lowering head, inhale spine up, abs in and upward
Sharabhasana from Chatuspadasana with deep breathing
Inhale right leg back high, exhale to Chatuspada
Inhale left leg high, exhale to Chatuspada
Exhale right knee to nose, return
Sasha Vyagraha: Integration of all movements
Maintain awareness of complete lung expansion throughout
techniques.focus_technique: Complete lung awareness - front 3x, side 3x, back 3x encompassing all regions
techniques.sequence: Complete integration of all previous sequences with full body awareness
techniques.post_practice: Extended integration: Mukha Bhastrika 3 times  Dharmikasana  Suptha Vajrasana  Vajrasana  Turn mat north-south  Kaya Kriya 3x each  All together 3x  With Pranav  Extended Savasana with polarity Savitri breath 20 minutes
contraindications: Should only be practiced after mastering individual phases
Avoid if experiencing any respiratory distress
Stop if feeling overwhelmed or dizzy

dosha_information.effects: Completely balances nervous system, integrates all body systems
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Master practice for complete constitutional balance

guna_information.effects: Promotes complete integration, spiritual awareness, and inner harmony

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Complete lung expansion from lower to upper regions
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Full retention engaging all lung capacity
breathing_pattern.out_rechaka: Complete exhalation from upper to lower regions

techniques.sanskrit_meaning: Mahat = great/complete; Integration of all breathing patterns
techniques.traditional_source: Hathenas system from Swami Gitananda tradition
additional_notes: Culminating practice of the Hathenas lung expansion system
Integrates physical, energetic, and mental aspects
Best practiced as complete sequence: Adham  Madhyam  Adhyama  Mahat
Represents mastery of complete respiratory function

techniques.name: Kaya Kriya (Cellular Memory Release Practice)
techniques.description: A powerful yogic technique combining coordinated breath, movement, and sound to release trauma stored in the cellular memory of the brain. This practice systematically engages different body parts with specific breathing patterns and mantric sounds.
techniques.primary_goal: Release trauma stuck in cellular memory of brain
techniques.overview: Kaya Kriya is performed in four progressive steps, each building upon the previous to create a complete mind-body integration practice that addresses stored trauma at the cellular level.

steps.description: Focus on lower body and diaphragmatic breathing

inhalation.awareness: Draw energy into lower body and pelvic region

exhalation.awareness: Release tension and trauma from lower body

steps.description: Focus on heart center and emotional release

inhalation.awareness: Open heart space and emotional center

exhalation.awareness: Release emotional blocks and heart-stored trauma

steps.description: Focus on mental clearing and upper body release

inhalation.awareness: Activate upper respiratory and mental faculties

exhalation.awareness: Release mental tension and cognitive trauma patterns

steps.description: Complete integration of all body parts and breath regions

inhalation.action: Toes in + Arms out + Head right (simultaneously)
inhalation.awareness: Total body-mind integration and energy unification

exhalation.action: Toes out + Arms in + Head left (simultaneously)
exhalation.sound: AA-OOO-MMM (combined sounds in sequence or simultaneously)
exhalation.awareness: Complete release of stored trauma from all body systems

techniques.setup: Lie down in a comfortable supine position (Shavasana). Ensure the spine is straight and the body is relaxed. Begin with natural breathing to center yourself.
detailed_instructions: Begin in Shavasana with natural breathing
Practice each step separately first, then combine:
Step 1: Focus only on legs and lower lung breathing with AA sound
Step 2: Focus only on arms and middle lung breathing with OOOO sound
Step 3: Focus only on head and upper lung breathing with MMMM sound
Step 4: Integrate all movements, breath regions, and sounds together
Focus on releasing rather than forcing
End with several minutes of stillness in Shavasana

breathing_pattern.in_puraka: Progressive lung expansion (lowermiddleupper or all together)
breathing_pattern.kumbaka: Brief natural retention allowing energy integration
breathing_pattern.shunyaka: Natural pause allowing cellular release and integration

AA_sound.effect: Grounds energy, releases pelvic and lower body trauma

OOO_sound.effect: Opens emotional blocks, releases heart-stored trauma

MMM_sound.effect: Clears mental patterns, releases cognitive trauma
MMM_sound.resonance: Throat, third eye, and crown chakras

benefits: Releases trauma stored in cellular memory
contraindications: Practice gently with recent trauma - seek professional guidance
Not recommended during active psychotic episodes
Stop if experiencing flashbacks or dissociation

dosha_information.effects: Calms scattered nervous system, grounds anxious energy, releases stored tension
dosha_information.therapeutic_use: Excellent for Vata imbalances related to trauma, anxiety, and nervous system disorders

guna_information.effects: Promotes clarity, peace, and release of negative mental patterns stored in cellular memory

practice_guidelines.frequency: Daily practice for trauma recovery, 2-3 times weekly for maintenance
practice_guidelines.duration: 10-20 minutes initially, can extend to 30 minutes with experience
practice_guidelines.timing: Morning for energizing, evening for releasing daily stress
practice_guidelines.environment: Quiet, safe space where emotional release is comfortable
practice_guidelines.progression: Master individual steps before attempting integration

traditional_context.sanskrit_meaning: Kaya = body; Kriya = action/cleansing; Body purification practice
traditional_context.lineage: Part of Kriya Yoga tradition focusing on psychophysical purification
traditional_context.philosophy: Based on understanding that trauma is stored in cellular memory and can be released through conscious breath-movement-sound coordination

integration_notes: This practice may bring up emotions - this is normal and healing
The body has its own wisdom for release
Trauma release happens in layers over time
Consistency is more important than intensity
End practice with gratitude and self-compassion
techniques.ratio_info: Natural breath rhythm, not counted - focus on quality of awareness rather than timing
additional_notes: One of the most powerful practices for trauma release in yoga therapy
Combines ancient wisdom with modern understanding of trauma storage
Can be adapted for different physical abilities
May be practiced seated if lying down is not comfortable
The sound vibrations help release trauma at a cellular level
Integration step (Step 4) represents wholeness after fragmentation
